unnormalised: ## The EMI Maze: My Quest for a Home Loan
normalised: ## The E-M-I Maze: My Quest for a Home Loan

unnormalised: Buying a home in Mumbai seemed like a distant dream. I, like many middle-class Indians, always thought of it as something only achievable much later in life, if at all. Rent was eating up a significant portion of my salary – about 40% to be precise – and the idea of building equity felt incredibly appealing. But the sheer size of property prices in the city, often quoted in crores (1 crore = 10 million), was daunting.
normalised: Buying a home in Mumbai seemed like a distant dream. I, like many middle-class Indians, always thought of it as something only achievable much later in life, if at all. Rent was eating up a significant portion of my salary – about forty percent to be precise – and the idea of building equity felt incredibly appealing. But the sheer size of property prices in the city, often quoted in crores (one crore equals ten million), was daunting.

unnormalised: My journey started with countless online searches. I scoured websites comparing interest rates offered by different banks. HDFC, ICICI, SBI – they all seemed to have a confusing array of loan products. Some offered fixed rates, others floating. The fine print was a nightmare – processing fees, prepayment penalties, insurance costs – it all added up. I saw rates advertised as low as 8.25% p.a. but quickly realized that was often just a teaser rate for the first year.
normalised: My journey started with countless online searches. I scoured websites comparing interest rates offered by different banks. H-D-F-C, I-C-I-C-I, S-B-I – they all seemed to have a confusing array of loan products. Some offered fixed rates, others floating. The fine print was a nightmare – processing fees, prepayment penalties, insurance costs – it all added up. I saw rates advertised as low as eight point two five percent p.a. but quickly realized that was often just a teaser rate for the first year.

unnormalised: I remember visiting my local SBI branch. The loan officer, Mr. Sharma, was helpful but overloaded with paperwork. He patiently explained the different types of loans available and asked for a mountain of documents: salary slips for the last 3 months, Form 16, ITR returns for the last 2 years, property documents, Aadhaar card, PAN card...the list seemed endless.
normalised: I remember visiting my local S-B-I branch. The loan officer, Mister Sharma, was helpful but overloaded with paperwork. He patiently explained the different types of loans available and asked for a mountain of documents: salary slips for the last three months, Form sixteen, I-T-R returns for the last two years, property documents, Aadhaar card, P-A-N card...the list seemed endless.

unnormalised: The initial loan amount I was eligible for was Rs. 75 lakh. Not bad, but still not enough to buy the 2BHK I had my eye on in Andheri. I considered increasing the loan tenure to 30 yrs to reduce the EMI, but the thought of being in debt for that long felt scary. Plus, the total interest paid over such a long period would be significantly higher.
normalised: The initial loan amount I was eligible for was rupee seventy five lakh. Not bad, but still not enough to buy the two B-H-K I had my eye on in Andheri. I considered increasing the loan tenure to thirty years to reduce the E-M-I, but the thought of being in debt for that long felt scary. Plus, the total interest paid over such a long period would be significantly higher.

unnormalised: My friend, Aisha, who works in finance, suggested I improve my credit score. She explained that a CIBIL score of 750 or higher could get me a better interest rate. I checked my credit score on Paisabazaar.com and saw it was hovering around 720. Time to fix that!
normalised: My friend, Aisha, who works in finance, suggested I improve my credit score. She explained that a C-I-B-I-L score of seven hundred and fifty or higher could get me a better interest rate. I checked my credit score on Paisabazaar.com and saw it was hovering around seven hundred and twenty. Time to fix that!

unnormalised: I made sure to pay all my credit card bills on time, reducing my outstanding balances and avoiding any late payment fees. Within 6 months, my CIBIL score improved to 780. This made a noticeable difference when I reapplied for the loan.
normalised: I made sure to pay all my credit card bills on time, reducing my outstanding balances and avoiding any late payment fees. Within six months, my C-I-B-I-L score improved to seven hundred and eighty. This made a noticeable difference when I reapplied for the loan.

unnormalised: Finally, after what felt like an eternity, my loan was approved. The EMI came out to be Rs. 63,000 per month. It's a substantial amount, but knowing that I'm building equity and finally owning a piece of Mumbai makes it all worthwhile. The flat number is B-204, and hopefully in the coming years its value will only appreciate, offsetting the interest I’ll pay back on this loan!
normalised: Finally, after what felt like an eternity, my loan was approved. The E-M-I came out to be rupee sixty three thousand per month. It's a substantial amount, but knowing that I'm building equity and finally owning a piece of Mumbai makes it all worthwhile. The flat number is B-two hundred and four, and hopefully in the coming years its value will only appreciate, offsetting the interest I’ll pay back on this loan!

unnormalised: The entire process taught me a lot about the world of finance and the importance of financial planning. From navigating complex loan terms to understanding credit scores, I now feel more confident in managing my money and making informed financial decisions. And the best part? I finally have a place to call home.
